content: The "Safe Highways and Infrastructure Preservation Act of 1997" prohibits the operation of certain cargo-carrying units on federally assisted highways, amending Section 411 of the Surface Transportation Assistance Act of 1982 to impose length limitations. Enforcement changes involve amending the 2nd sentence of section 141(b) of title 23, United States Code. SEC. 3. TERMINATION OF DETERMINATIONS OF GRANDFATHER RIGHTS. Section 127 of title 23, United States Code, is amended to include a provision on Grandfather Rights, stating that no State can allow the operation of any vehicle not in conformance with Interstate weight limits unless it is on a published list determined by the Secretary of Transportation. The provision on Grandfather Rights in Section 127 of title 23, United States Code, prohibits States from allowing the operation of vehicles that do not comply with Interstate weight limits unless they are on a list determined by the Secretary of Transportation. This list must include vehicles that could lawfully operate in a State before January 1, 1997, and on July 1, 1956, with certain limitations. The final list must be published within 270 days of the enactment of this provision. The Secretary will publish a final list of vehicles or combinations within 270 days. States can reduce weight limitations for vehicles on the list, but not below the limits in subsection (a). Vehicles on the list must adhere to specific designations in force. The text discusses the implementation of specific designations for vehicles in force before January 1, 1997, with a conforming amendment to section 127(a) of the title. SEC. 4. NONDIVISIBLE LOAD PROCEEDING. Section 127 of title 23, United States Code, is amended to include a proceeding to determine the meaning of 'vehicles and loads which cannot be easily dismantled or divided' and issue final regulations within 270 days. These regulations will apply to all loads on the National Highway System, with states allowed to establish additional requirements. The policy of this title is to promote conformity with Interstate weight limits for the benefit and safety of all motorists, defined as specific weight limitations for vehicles on the Interstate. SEC. 5. WEIGHT LIMITATIONS. Title 23, United States Code, is amended to include new section 127a regarding gross vehicle weight and axle loading limitations on non-Interstate highways on the National Highway System. The limitations set by State statute as of January 1, 1997, will apply to all vehicles and combinations on non-Interstate highways, with exceptions as provided by subsection (c). The Secretary will publish a list of State weight and axle limitations for non-Interstate highways, with a final list due within 180 days. Additionally, a list of nonconforming operations will be published. The Secretary will publish a final list of State weight and axle limitations for non-Interstate highways within 180 days, including nonconforming operations. All vehicles on the list must adhere to existing routing-specific, commodity-specific, and weight-specific designations in force in the State. The limitations established by subsection (a) apply to new designations on the National Highway System and non-Interstate highways. States can reduce weight limitations on existing non-Interstate highways. Interstate weight limits are defined as 80,000 pounds gross vehicle weight, 20,000 pounds single axle weight, and 34,000 pounds.
